results.title: Hunt
results.creator_credit: David Deverell and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Short story showcase”.
A hunting trip turns into a deadly manhunt, touching on themes of man’s relationship to his environment, animals and other people. Adapted from a story by Richard Connell.

results.title: Dr Heidegger's experiment
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Short story showcase”.
An adaptation of Nathaniel Hawthorne’s symbolic tale of a wise old doctor who proves to his friends that age and wisdom are not necessarily synonymous.

results.title: A Discussion of Herman Melville's 'Bartleby'
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Short story showcase”.
The student is given an opportunity to develop his own independent critical analysis of the book and then to compare his ideas with those of the critic Charles Van Doren who has considered the work in depth. Explores the many possibilities for creative interpretation.

results.title: A Discussion of Fyodor Dostoyevsky's 'The Crocodile'
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Short story showcase”.
Commentator Clifton Fadiman discusses various themes and ideas presented in the short story “The Crocodile” by Dostoyevsky, and he points out the significance of the themes in relation to the life of the author and certain events in Russian history.

results.title: A Discussion of Frank Stockton's 'The Lady, or the tiger?'
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Short story showcase”.
A study of the classic short story by American writer, Frank R. Stockton. Uses “historical” footage interspersed with dramatic narrative finishing with taunting question of suitor’s choice of doom - the tiger or the lady.

results.title: The Crocodile
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Short story showcase”.
In Dostoyevsky’s unfinished story “The Crocodile”, the genteel life of a Russian middle-class social circle is disrupted in an unusual way - one of its members is swallowed by a crocodile. To everyone’s surprise, though - including his own - the swallowed Ivan Matveyevitch finds life inside the reptile quite bearable. Realising that his presence inside the crocodile adds considerably to the animal’s value as a sideshow attraction, the practical and public-spirited Ivan readily accepts the opportunity to help increase the value of capital. His wife and friend are somewhat concerned for his welfare, but Ivan refuses to be rescued. “The principles of economics come first”, he says. Cast includes: Eldon Quick, Robyn Millan, Britt Leach. Adapted for the screen from the book of the same title.

results.title: Shaun Tan's The Lost Thing: From book to film. The Interviews
results.creator_credit: Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’ tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeon holes.
Melbourne-based production company Passion Pictures Australia invited Shaun to direct an animated version of ‘The Lost Thing’, and several years later, the Oscar®-winning short film emerged.
The ACMI exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From book to film’(showing in Gallery Two from 16th July 2013 to 19th January 2014), features Shaun’s exquisite original drawings and working sketches alongside exclusive footage of the animators and sound artists, demonstrating how the drawings were brought to life on screen with movement, sound effects, music and narration.
These eight interview segments are each based on a particular production process in the making of ‘The Lost Thing’.
The eight segments feature interviews with Shaun Tan (writer/co director), Sophie Byrne (producer), Tom Bryant (3D artist), Leo Baker (animator), John Kassab (sound designer) and Michael Yezerski (composer).
In addition to the interviews, there is a wealth of ‘behind-the-scenes’ footage, rough drafts of designs and animation wireframes from the very early stages of production.
